reasoning:
Both essays demonstrate a very high level of quality for Criterion B, but Essay B is slightly superior due to its more thorough and practical considerations in its methodology and risk assessment.

First, both essays present exceptionally strong and well-defined research questions. Essay A asks, "What is the effect of changing the acid to conjugate base ([A-]/[HA]) concentration ratio (19, 3, 1, 0.333, 0.0526) on the buffering capacity...". Similarly, Essay B asks, "How does the voltage increase (2V, 4V, 6V, 8V, 10V) in an electrolytic cell affect the percentage mass increase of a copper-nickel cathode after a 10-minute interval?". Both questions are commendable for their specificity, clearly stating the exact values of the independent variable to be tested and the precise metric for the dependent variable.

In terms of background information, both are focused and relevant. Essay A provides a detailed chemical foundation, explaining buffer systems, the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, and two different formulas for buffer capacity, demonstrating significant theoretical depth. Essay B effectively links a personal interest in jewellery making to the scientific principles of electroplating, referencing Faraday's law and citing several previous studies, which strengthens its academic context.

However, Essay B's methodology and consideration of variables are slightly more robust. For its controlled variables, Essay B provides more detailed methods of control, for instance, for the distance between electrodes it states, "using a wooden splint placed across the beaker... mark where either ends of the beaker are located on it. This will indicate where the copper wire will be wrapped around to ensure that the same distance is kept". This is more meticulous than Essay A's more general plan to "monitored vigilantly" the temperature.

The most significant differentiator is the treatment of safety, ethical, and environmental considerations. Both are experimental labs and correctly address all three areas. However, Essay B's environmental section is far more detailed and actionable. It suggests specific disposal methods, stating "remainder pure copper sulphate solution can be heated up in an evaporating basin to form copper sulphate crystals in other experiments" and that "Sulphuric acid can be neutralized with sodium carbonate". This contrasts with Essay A's more general statement that "A low concentration will have no significant environmental effects," which lacks specific disposal instructions. This superior attention to the practical and responsible aspects of the investigation gives Essay B the edge.
